elements.content: A new family of organic–inorganic hybrid layered materials based on cadmium and zinc sulfates was synthesized using 1,2-phenylenediamine (OPD), 1,3-phenylenediamine (MPD), and 1,4-phenylenediamine (PPD) as organic templates and ligands. The diamines act as structure-directing agents to obtain one-dimensional (1D), 2D, and 3D frameworks. Six new materials were obtained utilizing a simple, solvent-free synthesis approach: 1D: (OPD)2ZnSO4 1, (OPD)2CdSO4 2; 2D: (MPD)2ZnSO4 3, (MPD)2CdSO4 4; 3D: (PPD)­ZnSO4 5, (PPD)­CdSO4 6. The synthesis method proved to be scalable and robust. The crystal structures were determined using data from X-ray powder diffraction measurements (XRPD). It was observed that the type of amine determines the dimensionality of the obtained materials. 1D, 2D, and 3D structures were obtained using ortho-, meta-, and para-phenylenediamine isomers, respectively. The phase purity of the samples was confirmed by elemental analysis, and the morphology of the crystallites was studied using scanning electron microscopy. The thermal stability was determined by thermogravimetry and nonambient XRPD techniques. Additional characterization was performed for the two non-centrosymmetric, polar materials 3 and 4. Second-order nonlinear optical properties were examined using both experimental measurements (second harmonic generation) and theoretical calculations.

The diamines act as structure-directing agents to obtain one-dimensional (1D), 2D, and 3D frameworks. Six new materials were obtained utilizing a simple, solvent-free synthesis approach: 1D: (OPD)2ZnSO4 1, (OPD)2CdSO4 2; 2D: (MPD)2ZnSO4 3, (MPD)2CdSO4 4; 3D: (PPD)ZnSO4 5, (PPD)CdSO4 6. elements.content: New organic−inorganic hybrid layered materials based on metal sulfates were synthesized using diamine isomers as organic ligands. The diamines act as structure-directing agents to obtain 1D, 2D, and 3D frameworks. A solvent-free synthesis method was used. The crystal structures were determined using X-ray powder diffraction technique. Thermal stability and morphology were studied, and additional characterization was performed for the non-centrosymmetric materials.

elements.content: Hybrid organic–inorganic materials have been intensively investigated for at least three decades. Nevertheless, new interesting compounds are still being discovered due to a large variety of available organic and inorganic components, as well as emerging synthesis techniques using different experimental conditions. It has been shown that hybrid organic–inorganic compounds play a prominent role in the development of new advanced functional materials. Because of the complementary properties of the organic (flexibility and structural diversity) and inorganic (rigidity and stability) components, these materials are suitable for many applications in areas such as optoelectronics, environmental protection, or catalysis. The structure diversity of hybrid materials gives almost limitless possibilities of obtaining crystals with different properties. However, controlling the magnitude of a particular physical effect often requires steering of molecular self-assembly. There is no direct recipe for a successful design of all functional materials; however, we can retain some degree of control through crystal engineering. The literature reports show that temperature, pH value, stoichiometry, and template molecules have a great influence on the reaction outcome. Nevertheless, a “single set of factors” that determines the dimensionality of the resulting framework of a hybrid organic–inorganic material has not been identified. Although many different organic molecule types have been used as templates it is well-known that amines and diamines are very important building blocks in the synthesis of hybrid materials. Paul et al. and Liu et al. present good examples of aromatic amines (specifically, polyazaheterocycles and triazole derivates) used as organic block and cadmium sulfates as inorganic part, where two-dimensional (2D) and 3D frameworks were synthesized. The use of different structural isomers as organic building blocks was previously studied by Thirumurugan and Rao and Zheng He et al. Thirumurugan and Rao presented a group of hybrid compounds that contain isomers of benzenedicarboxylic acid as organic components in the presence or absence of amines, acting as chelating ligands, and Zn or Cd as metal centers. However, because of the presence of linkers, chelating ligands, and solvent, the degree of control over the dimensionality of the crystal structures obtained with these isomers is not directly dependent upon the isomer type. Zheng He et al. synthesized a family of coordination polymers presenting a more systematic approach to a dimensionality-controlled method by using pyridine carboxylate N-oxide isomers and Gd­(III) salts. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of a solvent-free synthesis of hybrid materials engineered with specific dimensionality depending directly on the isomers of the organic component.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Hybrid organic-inorganic materials have been intensively investigated for at least three decades. Nevertheless, new interesting compounds are still being discovered due to a large variety of available organic and inorganic components, as well as emerging synthesis techniques using different experimental conditions. It has been shown that hybrid organic-inorganic compounds play a prominent role in the development of new advanced functional materials. Because of the complementary properties of the organic (flexibility and structural diversity) and inorganic (rigidity and stability) components, these materials are suitable for many applications in areas such as optoelectronics, environmental protection, or catalysis. The structure diversity of hybrid materials gives almost limitless possibilities of obtaining crystals with different properties. However, controlling the magnitude of a particular physical effect often requires steering of molecular self-assembly. There is no direct recipe for a successful design of all functional materials; however, we can retain some degree of control through crystal engineering. The literature reports show that temperature, pH value, stoichiometry, and template molecules have a great influence on the reaction outcome. Nevertheless, a "single set of factors" that determines the dimensionality of the resulting framework of a hybrid organic-inorganic material has not been identified. Although many different organic molecule types have been used as templates it is well-known that amines and diamines are very important building blocks in the synthesis of hybrid materials. Paul et al. and Liu et al. present good examples of aromatic amines (specifically, polyazaheterocycles and triazole derivates) used as organic block and cadmium sulfates as inorganic part, where two-dimensional (2D) and 3D frameworks were synthesized. The use of different structural isomers as organic building blocks was previously studied by Thirumurugan and Rao and Zheng He et al. Thirumurugan and Rao presented a group of hybrid compounds that contain isomers of benzenedicarboxylic acid as organic components in the presence or absence of amines, acting as chelating ligands, and Zn or Cd as metal centers. However, because of the presence of linkers, chelating ligands, and solvent, the degree of control over the dimensionality of the crystal structures obtained with these isomers is not directly dependent upon the isomer type. Zheng He et al. synthesized a family of coordination polymers presenting a more systematic approach to a dimensionality-controlled method by using pyridine carboxylate N-oxide isomers and Gd(III) salts. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of a solvent-free synthesis of hybrid materials engineered with specific dimensionality depending directly on the isomers of the organic component.

elements.content: We wanted to focus on a simple, robust, solvent-free synthesis method using just aromatic diamines and a metal sulfate (Cd/Zn). Herein, six new hybrid materials were obtained, where the aromatic diamine acts as a structure-directing agent to systematically tune the framework dimensionality using similar organic building blocks. Polymeric 1D chains, 2D layers, and 3D structures were obtained when ortho-, meta-, or para-phenylenediamines were used, respectively.

Herein, six new hybrid materials were obtained, where the aromatic diamine acts as a structure-directing agent to systematically tune the framework dimensionality using similar organic building blocks. Polymeric 1D chains, 2D layers, and 3D structures were obtained when ortho-, meta-, or para-phenylenediamines were used, respectively.

elements.content: In our previous research meta- and para-xylylenediamine materials with Zn and Cd sulfates were investigated. It was observed that meta-xylylenediamine has a tendency to crystallize in non-centrosymmetric space groups. Because of this, it was also interesting to confirm a correlation between the lack of inversion center and the meta isomer. In fact, we obtained two new polar materials using the meta isomer and tested them in the context of nonlinear optical properties (NLO). We examined second harmonic generation (SHG), for the powdered samples 3 and 4, which is a known second-order NLO effect. It is well-known that only materials without an inversion center can exhibit nonlinear optical properties of even orders. Thus, the observation of SGH signal from a powdered sample provided additional proof of non-centrosymmetricity of the examined crystals.

elements.content: ZnSO4·7H2O and CdSO4·8/3H2O (Avantor Performance Materials Poland S.A.), o-phenylenediamine (OPD; C8H12N2), p-phenylenediamine (PPD; C8H12N2), and m-phenylenediamine (MPD; C8H12N2) (99%, Sigma-Aldrich) were used as received without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

ZnSO4⋅7H2O and CdSO4⋅8/3H2O (Avantor Performance Materials Poland S.A.), o-phenylenediamine (OPD; C8H12N2), p-phenylenediamine (PPD; C8H12N2), and m-phenylenediamine (MPD; C8H12N2) (99%, Sigma-Aldrich) were used as received without further purification.

elements.content: All materials were synthesized by heating the reagents in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. No solvent or excess of any reactant was used. The final products crystallized as fine powders. (OPD)2ZnSO4 1, (OPD)2CdSO4 2, (MPD)2ZnSO4 3, and (MPD)2CdSO4 4. Twenty millimoles (2.16 g) of the corresponding amine (MPD or OPD) and 10 mmol of the metal sulfate, (1.79 g) ZnSO4·H2O for 1 and 3; or 10 mmol (2.56 g) of CdSO4·8/3H2O for 2 and 4; were weighed and transferred to a 60-ml sealed Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reactants were heated at 120 °C for 3 d and left to cool to room temperature. Afterward, the products were washed with propanol (×2) and left to dry at room temperature for 12 h to obtain the final powder products. Anal. Calcd (%) for ZnSO4C12H16N4 1: (377.7 g·mol–1): C, 38.15; H, 4.27; N, 14.83. Found C, 38.04; H, 4.43; N 14.61. Yield: ca. 94%. Anal. Calcd (%) for CdSO4C12H16N4 2: (424.8 g·mol–1): C, 33.93; H, 3.80; N, 13.19. Found C, 34.16; H, 3.43; N, 13.50. Yield: ca. 89.2%. Anal. Calcd (%) for 3 ZnSO4C12H16N4 (377.3 g·mol–1): C, 38.15; H, 4.27; N, 14.83. Found C, 37.90; H, 4.12; N, 14.59. Yield: ca. 92.7%. Anal. Calcd (%) for CdSO4C12H16N4 4 (424.8 g·mol–1): C, 33.93; H, 3.80; N, 13.19. Found C, 33.74; H 3.67; N, 12.86. Yield: ca. 93.1%. (PPD)­ZnSO4 5 and (PPD)­CdSO4 6. Ten millimoles (1.08 g) of 1,4-phenylenediamine and 10 mmol (1.08 g) of ZnSO4·H2O for 5; or 10 mmol (2.56 g) of 8CdSO4·3H2O for 6; were weighed and transferred to a 60 ml sealed Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, heated at 120 °C for 3 d, and left to cool to room temperature. The products were washed with a mixture of water and propanol 1:1 (×2) and left to dry at room temperature for 12 h to obtain a final powder product. Anal. Calcd (%) for ZnSO4C6H8N2 5 (269.6 g·mol–1): C, 26.74; H, 2.99; N, 10.39. Found C, 27.3; H, 3.34; N, 10.70. Yield: ca. 93.3%. Anal. Calcd (%) for CdSO4C6H8N2 6 (316.6 g·mol–1): C, 22.76; H, 2.54; N, 8.85. Found C, 22.64; H, 2.55; N, 8.81 Yield: ca. 92.8%. Additionally, the synthesis of all materials was performed several times proving the robustness of the method as well as its scalability in the “laboratory scale range” (scaled up to 6 times). The crystallographic data for the compounds 1–6 were deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC). The CCDC numbers for the compounds are 1–1521451, 2–1521452, 3–1521455, 4–1521450, 5–1521454, and 6–1521453.

elements.content: X-ray powder diffraction measurements (XRPD) were performed with an X’Pert PRO MPD diffractometer working in Bragg–Brentano geometry: incident and antiscatter slits of 1/4 and 1/2°; X-ray source: LFF tube, copper anode Cu Kα (1.541 78 Å); operating power: 40 kV and 30 mA. The diffraction patterns were recorded at room temperature in the range of 4–90° 2θ; interpolated step size: 0.02°; detector: PIXCEL. Nonlinear optical activity: SHG experiments were done using SURELITE II Nd:YAG pulsed laser with removed SHG and third harmonic generation units for obtaining pure infrared beam. Elemental analyses were performed with a Euro Vector EA 3000 Elemental Analyzer. Thermal analysis: thermogravimetric (TG) analyses of the materials were completed on a TA Discovery thermal analyzer by TA Instruments, with an absolute weighing error of less than 1 μg and weight measurement resolution of less than 0.1 μg. The initial sample mass for all materials was 20 mg. The measurements were performed under an air atmosphere. The heating rate was 1 °C/min; the initial temperature was set to 20 °C, and the end point was set to 800 °C. The TG furnace was purged with air at a rate of 100 mL/min. Nonambient XRPD analysis was performed under an air atmosphere using a reaction chamber produced by Anton Paar. The measurements were recorded every 25 °C from room temperature to 150 °C; above this temperature the measurements were recorded every 50 to 800 °C; the heating rate was 10 °C/min. Sample morphology: TESCAN VEGA3 LMU scanning electron microscope with a LaB6 emitter; the accelerating voltage was 20 kV. The samples were sputter-coated with gold using a Quorum Q150R coater.

elements.content: The crystal structures were determined using data obtained by XRPD experiments, since all materials were obtained as fine powders. The cell parameters were found using the NTREOR program. Atomic positions were determined by direct space methods using FOX for (1) to (4); for (5) and (6), the atoms of the inorganic part were located by direct methods with the use of EXPO2014. The structure refinement of all materials was performed with the profile method implemented in JANA2006.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Solution

The crystal structures were determined using data obtained by XRPD experiments, since all materials were obtained as fine powders. The cell parameters were found using the NTREOR program. Atomic positions were determined by direct space methods using FOX for (1) to (4); for (5) and (6), the atoms of the inorganic part were located by direct methods with the use of EXPO2014. The structure refinement of all materials was performed with the profile method implemented in JANA2006.

elements.content:
The thermal behavior of each material was studied using thermogravimetric (TG) analysis and nonambient XRPD. presents the TG profiles of the studied materials heated in air.

For all materials, the first small weight-loss step (1) corresponds to water or weakly bonded amine adsorbed at the surface. Later, the remaining amine is removed either alone (2) or together with SO x /O2 (3). In some cases, a fourth step with only SO x /O2 (4) removal is also present, leaving ZnO or a mixture of CdSO4 and Cd2OSO4 as the final residue depending on the starting material. All the final residues were identified by XRPD. A summary of the decomposition steps is given in . Details are presented in Figures SI-2–SI-7.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Thermal Analysis

The thermal behavior of each material was studied using thermogravimetric (TG) analysis and nonambient XRPD.  presents the TG profiles of the studied materials heated in air.

For all materials, the first small weight-loss step (1) corresponds to water or weakly bonded amine adsorbed at the surface. Later, the remaining amine is removed either alone (2) or together with SO x /O2 (3). In some cases, a fourth step with only SO x /O2 (4) removal is also present, leaving ZnO or a mixture of CdSO4 and Cd2OSO4 as the final residue depending on the starting material. All the final residues were identified by XRPD. A summary of the decomposition steps is given in . Details are presented in Figures SI-2-SI-7.

On the basis of these results, it is clearly visible that the stability of the materials increases with their dimensionality. Polymeric compounds 1 and 2 are stable up to ∼180 °C, whereas 2D 3 and 4 are stable up to ∼230 °C. 3D compounds 5 and 6 are the most stable (up to ∼320 °C). For 3D compounds, the decomposition process occurs in a diffused single step. However, it is necessary to emphasize that it is not possible to mark a point between the amine and SO x release step because of a high degree of overlap of these processes. This situation is more evident in 3D compounds 5 and 6, since the weight loss corresponding to the amine is initiated at higher temperatures than for the other materials. The TG results were verified by nonambient XRPD measurements (Figures SI-8–SI-13).

elements.content: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of investigated materials are presented in . Images of 1 and 2 show aggregates of platelike prisms of crystallites of sizes ∼100 × 500 × 1000 nm with well-developed surfaces and edges. Similar results are observed for 4 and 6. Materials 3 and 5 present similar plate aggregates, though they are much thinner; shapes and sizes are more diverse (estimated sizes are 100 × 200 × 500 nm). Quality of the crystals presented therein is reflected in the narrow well-developed shape of the diffraction maxima observed in XRPD experiments. In general, zinc-based compounds exhibit more regular, well-separated crystals, while cadmium-based crystals seem to be covered by smaller crystallites. The dimensionality of the structures does not significantly influence their morphology. The elongated platelike morphology conforms well to the tendency for preferred orientation observed in some of the diffraction patterns 1, 2, and 4.
elements.clean_text:
SEM

Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of investigated materials are presented in . Images of 1 and 2 show aggregates of platelike prisms of crystallites of sizes ~100 × 500 × 1000 nm with well-developed surfaces and edges. Similar results are observed for 4 and 6. Materials 3 and 5 present similar plate aggregates, though they are much thinner; shapes and sizes are more diverse (estimated sizes are 100 × 200 × 500 nm). Quality of the crystals presented therein is reflected in the narrow well-developed shape of the diffraction maxima observed in XRPD experiments. In general, zinc-based compounds exhibit more regular, well-separated crystals, while cadmium-based crystals seem to be covered by smaller crystallites. The dimensionality of the structures does not significantly influence their morphology. The elongated platelike morphology conforms well to the tendency for preferred orientation observed in some of the diffraction patterns 1, 2, and 4.

elements.content: Bond lengths and bonding angles were restrained to typical values (metal center-related bonds were not restrained). Isotropic description of atomic displacement parameters was used in the calculations. For 1, 2, and 4, preferred orientation in the direction [100] was observed, and March–Dollase correction was used in the calculations. For 2 and 3 the first peaks, namely, (100) in 2 and (200) in 3, were excluded from the calculations to improve the stability of the refinement. This practice is sometimes used in cases of refinements based on patterns dominated by a single intense diffraction maximum that displays a strong asymmetry. Profile plots for all materials are presented in Figure SI-1 in Supporting Information. Selected crystallographic data for 1–6 are given in . For detailed crystallographic data see Table SI-2. Structural diagrams were made with Diamond 3.2 software. Selected bond distances for all materials are presented in Tables SI-2–SI-4 in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description

Bond lengths and bonding angles were restrained to typical values (metal center-related bonds were not restrained). Isotropic description of atomic displacement parameters was used in the calculations. For 1, 2, and 4, preferred orientation in the direction [100] was observed, and March-Dollase correction was used in the calculations. For 2 and 3 the first peaks, namely, (100) in 2 and (200) in 3, were excluded from the calculations to improve the stability of the refinement. This practice is sometimes used in cases of refinements based on patterns dominated by a single intense diffraction maximum that displays a strong asymmetry. Profile plots for all materials are presented in Figure SI-1 in Supporting Information. Selected crystallographic data for 1-6 are given in . For detailed crystallographic data see Table SI-2. Structural diagrams were made with Diamond 3.2 software. Selected bond distances for all materials are presented in Tables SI-2-SI-4 in the Supporting Information.

Materials 1 and 2 are isostructural and crystallize in the monoclinic system with the space group I2/a. The fundamental building block is presented in A. The asymmetric unit consists of 12 non-hydrogen atoms, four of which belong to the inorganic fragment, and the rest constitute the organic moiety. The metal atom is located in a special position of I2/a (4c, 1̅, 1/4, 1/4, 1/4) surrounded by atoms forming a distorted octahedron. The octahedron is formed by two oxygen atoms located at opposite vertices of the polyhedron, in the axial positions (atoms O1 and O1*, ), and four nitrogen atoms in equatorial positions (N1, N1*, N2, and N2*). The oxygen atoms O1 and O1* also belong to the tetrahedral sulfate anion, where the sulfur atom is located on a the I2/a special position (4e, 2, 1/4, y, 0). The connected octahedra and tetrahedra form zigzaglike chains propagating along the [001] direction (B). The nitrogen atoms located in the equatorial positions of the distorted octahedron belong to two symmetry-related diamines joined by dative bonds to the metal. The diamines are located on both sides of the inorganic chain along the [100] direction.

elements.content: Materials 3 and 4 crystallize in the monoclinic system in the non-centrosymmetric space group Cc; these compounds are isostructural. The asymmetric unit is formed by 22 non-hydrogen atoms: six belong to the inorganic part and the rest of the organic fragments. The fundamental building block can be seen in A. The metal atom is surrounded by atoms forming a distorted octahedron composed of two oxygen atoms located at opposite vertices of the polyhedron (O1 and O3, the axial positions), while the equatorial positions are occupied by two oxygen atoms (O2 and O4) and by two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N4, Table SI-3). Since the oxygen atoms belong to one sulfate anion binding in chelating mode, an openwork layer of MO4N2 octahedra and SO4 tetrahedra parallel to the (100) plane is formed (see B). The diamines act as terminal ligands with only one of the two nitrogen atoms of each molecule (N1 and N4) bonded to the metal atom linking the organic and inorganic parts. The material possesses a dimensionality equal to 2, as the openwork layers are separated from each other.

elements.content: Materials 5 and 6 are isostructural and crystallize in the orthorhombic system with the space group Cmcm. The essential features of these structures are presented in A,B. The asymmetric units consist of seven non-hydrogen atoms, four of which belong to the inorganic fragment and three to the organic molecule. The metal atom is lying on the special position (4c, m2m, 0, y, 1/4). Its coordination polyhedron is a distorted octahedron with two oxygen atoms located at opposite vertices of the polyhedron, that is, the axial positions (O1 and O1*). The equatorial positions are occupied by two oxygen atoms (O2 and O2*) belonging to the same sulfate anion (binding in chelating mode) and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N1*, opposite O2 and O2*, respectively, Table SI-4). The MO4N2 octahedra and sulfate tetrahedra create a brick-wall-like layer parallel to the (001) plane, similar to the ones observed in 3 and 4 (see B). The diamines are connected, by covalent bonds, to two metals atoms of adjacent inorganic layers, thus functioning as bridging ligands forming a 3D assembly. Comparison of the inorganic part and packing of the structural components of all materials can be observed in Figures SI-14 and SI-15, respectively.

elements.content: The described materials led us to make some generalization. Regarding OPD, the small separation between the nitrogen atoms of the amine groups (ca. 2.85 Å) makes it impossible for the diamine to bind in a bridging mode. The smallest distance between the neighboring metal centers in structures from 1–6 lies between ca. 4.9 and 5.4 Å. Because of this mismatch, as well as the fact that the amine groups separation is comparable to the edge of the polyhedron surrounding the metal center in analogous compounds, the only possible mode of bonding available in this case is the chelating mode. This makes 1D-chain frameworks available.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

The described materials led us to make some generalization. Regarding OPD, the small separation between the nitrogen atoms of the amine groups (ca. 2.85 Å) makes it impossible for the diamine to bind in a bridging mode. The smallest distance between the neighboring metal centers in structures from 1-6 lies between ca. 4.9 and 5.4 Å. Because of this mismatch, as well as the fact that the amine groups separation is comparable to the edge of the polyhedron surrounding the metal center in analogous compounds, the only possible mode of bonding available in this case is the chelating mode. This makes 1D-chain frameworks available.

elements.content: The PPD molecule has its amine groups on the opposite sides of the aromatic ring, making the bridging mode the only one available if bonding with both NH2 groups is considered. Additionally, the aromatic ring introduces significant rigidity to the framework. These considerations indicate that bridging between the two layers is a more probable mode of bonding for a PPD molecule in this type of structure leading to a 3D framework.

elements.content: The MPD molecule has a separation between the amine groups of ca. 4.95 Å, which does not allow for a chelating bonding mode. Because of these, the MPD molecules form bonds with only a single amine group, which limits the dimensionality of the resulting frameworks to 2D.

elements.content: The considerations given above aim at explaining the directing effect of the isomer of phenylenediamine on the dimensionality of the structures of obtained materials based on the analysis of the geometry of the organic molecules. The structures presented seem to substantiate this reasoning, but analysis of further compounds obtained with these materials will be necessary to evaluate whether they will follow the trends observed in this work.

elements.content: Similar 3D materials of the (Xamine)­MSO4 formula (where Xamine stands for m-xylylenediamine (MXDA) or p-xylylenediamine (PXDA) and M represents Cd or Zn) were previously described by us. These materials crystallize in space groups Pnma and P21 ma for (MXDA)­MSO4 and (PXDA)­MSO4, respectively. They are built of MSO4 (metal sulfates) inorganic layers linked by the aromatic diamines via metal–nitrogen bonds (M–N). Each metal atom is surrounded by atoms forming a distorted octahedron built of four oxygen and two nitrogen atoms (similar to 3–6). On the basis of their composition and on the topological analyses of the inorganic layers, which define the topology as 63 (found by TOPOS) for both types of materials(Xamine)­MSO4 and (amine)­MSO4the inorganic layers of these two families could be expected to be identical; nevertheless, this is not the case as is visible in A. For (Xamine)­MSO4, the rings formed by the metal and sulfate atoms are arranged in a pattern reflecting the plane group symmetry of pg, which is the symmetry of the projection of the space group P21 ma, and a subgroup of the symmetry of the projection of the space group Pnma, along the [010] direction. In the case of (MPD, PPD)­MSO4 (B), the rings are arranged in a pattern with cm plane symmetry group (reduced with regard to c2mm, which is the symmetry of the projection of Cmcm along the [001] direction).

They are built of MSO4 (metal sulfates) inorganic layers linked by the aromatic diamines via metal-nitrogen bonds (M-N). Each metal atom is surrounded by atoms forming a distorted octahedron built of four oxygen and two nitrogen atoms (similar to 3-6). On the basis of their composition and on the topological analyses of the inorganic layers, which define the topology as 63 (found by TOPOS) for both types of materials(Xamine)MSO4 and (amine)MSO4the inorganic layers of these two families could be expected to be identical; nevertheless, this is not the case as is visible in A. For (Xamine)MSO4, the rings formed by the metal and sulfate atoms are arranged in a pattern reflecting the plane group symmetry of pg, which is the symmetry of the projection of the space group P21 ma, and a subgroup of the symmetry of the projection of the space group Pnma, along the [010] direction. In the case of (MPD, PPD)MSO4 (B), the rings are arranged in a pattern with cm plane symmetry group (reduced with regard to c2mm, which is the symmetry of the projection of Cmcm along the [001] direction).

elements.content: It is interesting to note that the type of arrangement of rings in both layers is different. For MXDA and PXDA the arrangement is of herringbone type, while in the case of 3–6, with MPD and PPD, it is brick-wall type. Another interesting point is the influence of the relative positions of the amine groups on the dimensionality of the framework. Concerning Xamines, the −NH2 groups are bound to sp3 carbon atoms that allow a high degree of rotational flexibility letting the amine groups connect to the metal atoms creating three-dimensional framework independently of the isomer of the amine that is used (meta or para), while in the case of OPD, MPD, and PPD the amine groups are bound to the aromatic ring directly, and relative positions of the nitrogen atoms cannot be altered due to the rigidity of the molecule. We can observe that changing the isomer of the organic component will lead to the same inorganic framework, but when the type of amine is changed the inorganic structure changes. This leads to an assumption that the driving force behind the formation of the specific structure of the inorganic assembly is, in fact, the type of the used amine. Future work will be dedicated to the elucidation of these observations.

elements.content: Static second-order electric susceptibility tensor χ ijk (2) components reflecting the magnitude of possible second-order NLO effects (e.g., SHG) were calculated using CPKS method implemented in Crystal17 software. The crystal structure of 3 was selected as a model one, and experimental geometry with X–H distances fitted to the neutron values was used for the initial assessment of χ(2). The theoretical values were obtained using B3LYP functional and B3LYP/POB-TZVP basis set for Zn and 6-311G for other atoms. Calculated values of refractive indices and χ(2) tensor components are presented in . Ground-state dipole moment was calculated for the Zn-complex ion cut from the crystal structure and for a larger cluster taking into account the polymeric nature of 3 using Gaussian09 and def2-TZVP/B3LYP basis sets.

When we look at the relative contributions of atoms building the crystal structure to the overall dipole moment calculated using QTAIM and AIMAll software () show a strong influence of the Zn–N bonds to the overall direction of the resultant dipole moment. This is not surprising, as those bonds are in fact stronger than Zn–O ones (more covalent character, as seen by the values of ρ­(r) and the ∇2ρ­(r), Table SI-5). Additionally, a large contribution comes also from the polymeric inorganic fragment of the structure. Note that the NLO-phore here is the meta-amine and that the observed nonlinear effects can be correlated with the mutual orientation of the chromophore molecules and SO4 2– ions. The obtained values are relatively small, which can be connected with lack of a proper push–pull organic NLO-phore molecules providing large values of molecular hyperpolarizability, which in fact could influence the magnitude of the bulk effect in the non-centrosymmetric crystal structure.

elements.content: The powder second harmonic generation (SHG) technique was developed by Kurtz and Perry to allow for measurements of the second-order nonlinear parameters of new materials without need of growing and cutting single crystals, saving time and resources. Details about the standard experimental setup could be found in Supporting Information. This technique was used to evaluate NLO properties of two new materials 3 and 4 with respect to reference powder of the well-known highly optically nonlinear KH2PO4 (KDP) crystal. Both the reference material and studied materials 3 and 4 were measured in identical irradiation conditions and geometry of light collection system that enabled us to compare their performance with the KDP standard. For each powder sample, SHG intensity versus incident pulse energy between 100 and 500 mJ, or until damage threshold was evaluated. This technique is excellent to evaluate NLO performance of a crystal, and through it is possible to confirm the non-centrosymmetricity of the material. SHG signals from samples 3 and 4, when excited with 200 mJ pulses (52 MW/cm2) of 1064 nm wavelength, appear exactly at λ = 532 nm (). The NLO responses of 3 and 4 are similar (SHG intensities ∼90 arbitrary units) differing only in the level of incoherent light scattering, Figure SI-17. This result suggests that the influence of metal (Zn or Cd) on the NLO effect is negligible and that the response is due to organic moieties and SO4 2– anions, which in this case are identical. The only noticed difference is the optical damage threshold. When 4 is excited with pulse energy 300 mJ or higher, it shows optical damage, as its SHG response diminishes considerably with each consecutive pulse, and the material shows darkening. The damage thresholds estimated from these experiments for 10 ns, 1064 nm laser light are 65 MW/cm2 for 4 and 140 MW/cm2 for 3. The optical damage threshold for KDP is estimated to be ∼500 MW/cm2. Comparison of SHG signals taken for the studied materials and KDP powder under the same excitation conditions is shown in .

Second Harmonic Generation Measurements

Details about the standard experimental setup could be found in Supporting Information. This technique was used to evaluate NLO properties of two new materials 3 and 4 with respect to reference powder of the well-known highly optically nonlinear KH2PO4 (KDP) crystal. Both the reference material and studied materials 3 and 4 were measured in identical irradiation conditions and geometry of light collection system that enabled us to compare their performance with the KDP standard. For each powder sample, SHG intensity versus incident pulse energy between 100 and 500 mJ, or until damage threshold was evaluated. This technique is excellent to evaluate NLO performance of a crystal, and through it is possible to confirm the non-centrosymmetricity of the material. The NLO responses of 3 and 4 are similar (SHG intensities ~90 arbitrary units) differing only in the level of incoherent light scattering, Figure SI-17. This result suggests that the influence of metal (Zn or Cd) on the NLO effect is negligible and that the response is due to organic moieties and SO4 2- anions, which in this case are identical. The only noticed difference is the optical damage threshold. When 4 is excited with pulse energy 300 mJ or higher, it shows optical damage, as its SHG response diminishes considerably with each consecutive pulse, and the material shows darkening. The damage thresholds estimated from these experiments for 10 ns, 1064 nm laser light are 65 MW/cm2 for 4 and 140 MW/cm2 for 3. The optical damage threshold for KDP is estimated to be ~500 MW/cm2. The estimated error of this measurement is ±10%. It is expected that if the microcrystals of these materials will be larger than their current size, that is, when exceeding the coherence lengths the measured, SHG signal could rise.

elements.content: Six new organic–inorganic hybrid compounds were synthesized using a simple, robust, and scalable solvent-free synthesis approach. Their crystal structures were obtained using X-ray powder diffraction data, since they crystallized as fine powders.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Six new organic-inorganic hybrid compounds were synthesized using a simple, robust, and scalable solvent-free synthesis approach. Their crystal structures were obtained using X-ray powder diffraction data, since they crystallized as fine powders.

elements.content: As we have shown in this paper, the different isomers of the phenylenediamine act as structure-directing agents by means of a solvent-free synthesis. Hence polymeric 1D chains, 2D layers, or 3D structures can be synthesized when ortho-, meta-, or para-phenylenediamines are used, respectively. In the case of 1D structures, the polymeric chain was built of MSO4 monomers. In 2D and 3D structures, the inorganic parts took the form of layers of MSO4 formula. In all cases, the metal atoms have distorted octahedral coordination: two oxygen and four nitrogen atoms for 1 and 2 and four oxygen and two nitrogen atoms for 3–6. In four compounds 1–4 the amine acts as a terminal ligand, while in 5 and 6 the organic molecule connects two adjacent inorganic layers. The thermal stability of the structures is strictly related to their dimensionality. On the basis of TG results, 3D materials are the most stable to ∼320 °C; 2D to ∼230 °C; and 1D to ∼180 °C, which are the temperatures at which amines molecules start to be removed. Materials 3 and 4 have non-centrosymmetric crystal structures. This was confirmed by experimental measurements of second harmonic generation, a second-order nonlinear optical effect that is possible only for non-centrosymmetric crystals. SHG signals were measured under excitation of 10 ns pulses at 1064 nm in 3 and 4; effective nonlinear susceptibilities were found to be nearly 8 times smaller than that measured for KDP crystala standard NLO material. The experimental findings were confronted with theoretical calculations. The observed discrepancies can easily be explained. The measurements were performed on a powder sample, which means that the obtained values are averaged over all possible orientations, whereas the calculations were performed for a crystal of 3. Both samples 3 and 4 are in the form of gray powders; they absorb light in the visible region, which greatly influences the efficiency of SHG process. Additionally, decomposition of the materials during the irradiation with a nanosecond laser light can be observed. The similarity of SHG efficiency for isostructural samples 3 and 4 proved that the obtained effect is not much dependent upon the metal center. Those substantial limitations do not allow us to conclude that 3 and 4 are materials with potential applications in optoelectronics; however, the observed SHG effect was an excellent way to confirm the non-centrosymmetricity of those materials.
elements.clean_text: As we have shown in this paper, the different isomers of the phenylenediamine act as structure-directing agents by means of a solvent-free synthesis. Hence polymeric 1D chains, 2D layers, or 3D structures can be synthesized when ortho-, meta-, or para-phenylenediamines are used, respectively. In the case of 1D structures, the polymeric chain was built of MSO4 monomers. In 2D and 3D structures, the inorganic parts took the form of layers of MSO4 formula. In all cases, the metal atoms have distorted octahedral coordination: two oxygen and four nitrogen atoms for 1 and 2 and four oxygen and two nitrogen atoms for 3-6. In four compounds 1-4 the amine acts as a terminal ligand, while in 5 and 6 the organic molecule connects two adjacent inorganic layers. The thermal stability of the structures is strictly related to their dimensionality. On the basis of TG results, 3D materials are the most stable to ~320 °C; 2D to ~230 °C; and 1D to ~180 °C, which are the temperatures at which amines molecules start to be removed. Materials 3 and 4 have non-centrosymmetric crystal structures. This was confirmed by experimental measurements of second harmonic generation, a second-order nonlinear optical effect that is possible only for non-centrosymmetric crystals. SHG signals were measured under excitation of 10 ns pulses at 1064 nm in 3 and 4; effective nonlinear susceptibilities were found to be nearly 8 times smaller than that measured for KDP crystala standard NLO material. The experimental findings were confronted with theoretical calculations. The observed discrepancies can easily be explained. The measurements were performed on a powder sample, which means that the obtained values are averaged over all possible orientations, whereas the calculations were performed for a crystal of 3. Both samples 3 and 4 are in the form of gray powders; they absorb light in the visible region, which greatly influences the efficiency of SHG process. Additionally, decomposition of the materials during the irradiation with a nanosecond laser light can be observed. The similarity of SHG efficiency for isostructural samples 3 and 4 proved that the obtained effect is not much dependent upon the metal center. Those substantial limitations do not allow us to conclude that 3 and 4 are materials with potential applications in optoelectronics; however, the observed SHG effect was an excellent way to confirm the non-centrosymmetricity of those materials.

elements.content: Improving optical performance would require a substantial change in the crystal composition. In the first stage, organic parts could be replaced with better NLO-phore molecules, which would influence the size of the bulk effect. Of course, polar crystal structure should be retained, and all of the remaining inorganic components should be chosen to minimize the possibility of obtaining crystals absorbing in the visible region.

In the first stage, organic parts could be replaced with better NLO-phore molecules, which would influence the size of the bulk effect. Of course, polar crystal structure should be retained, and all of the remaining inorganic components should be chosen to minimize the possibility of obtaining crystals absorbing in the visible region.

elements.content: The well-known high stability of Zn and Cd salts allowed us to treat these materials as models for a future group of functional materials. Our approach will be extended to similar metal–organic materials. We believe that proper selection of reagents, such as different sulfate salts, will yield new materials with catalytic and/or magnetic promising applications.

Our approach will be extended to similar metal-organic materials. We believe that proper selection of reagents, such as different sulfate salts, will yield new materials with catalytic and/or magnetic promising applications.
